Yes, there have been some studies that have explored how gender-segregated classrooms impact the emergence of LGBTQ students and their social well-being. One study found that students in single-sex schools reported feeling more comfortable expressing themselves and their sexuality outside of traditional gender roles than those in co-ed schools. Another study found that LGBTQ students in single-sex schools rated their school climate as more supportive than those in co-ed schools. 

However, it is important to note that not all single-sex schools are the same, and some may be more inclusive of LGBTQ students than others. Furthermore, LGBTQ students are a diverse group, and their experiences may differ based on their individual identities and the specific single-sex school they attend.

Overall, more research is needed to fully understand how gender-segregated classrooms impact the well-being and experiences of LGBTQ students. It is important for schools to work towards creating a safe, supportive environment for all students, including those who identify as LGBTQ, regardless of the school's gender-segregation model.
